item.title: Grants and fellowships
item.description:
A guide to applying for Grants and Fellowships

Welcome to this guide to applying for grants and fellowships for early career researchers competing for awards in the UK. The principles I set out here may also be broadly applicable to other settings but do take time to consider variations. The thoughts presented here are my own and my opinion is not universal but these ideas have served me well during my career and they may also be useful to you which is why I am creating this resource.

Assumptions

In writing this guide, I am assuming:

  • you have some interest in an academic career,
  • you are currently completing a PhD, working as a postdoc or in the initial stages of your first long-term academic appointment,
  • you have no or limited experience of applying for grants or fellowships as a principal investigator.

You may still find this guide a useful read if not all these conditions apply to you but this is the model which I have assumed.

Knowing why you want to do this

There are numerous reasons to apply for a research grant and fellowship but the common ones I can think of are given here:

Resources to conduct research.

In many situations, a research project simply cannot be undertaken unless there is financial support for it to be carried out. Mapping out those reasons can be very important for articulating why a grant or fellowship is required.

Pay your own salary

Many academic appointments are not permanent or conditional you receiving a definite amount of income from your grant or fellowship application successes.
